questions.text: Four days after undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft for coronary artery disease, a 60-year-old man has the onset of abdominal fullness and bloating. Since his surgery, he has not had a bowel movement and is unable to pass flatus. He has no nausea or vomiting. Prior to the operation, the patient had daily bowel movements without abnormalities. He has a history of bipolar disorder and hypertension. His current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, chlorpromazine, amlodipine, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows a distended, tympanic abdomen with guarding and rebound tenderness; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Abdominal x-ray shows diffuse distention of the colon loops. A CT scan with contrast confirms the x-ray findings and shows a cecal dilation of 14 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?

choices.text: Nasogastric and rectal tube insertion only
Intravenous fluid therapy and bowel rest only

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A nonsurgical approach to treating acute megacolon involves decompressing the stomach and the colon with nasogastric and rectal tubes, respectively. It is indicated in patients who only have mild symptoms and a cecal dilation < 12 cm. Because this patient has signs of peritonitis and his cecum is 14 cm in diameter, treatment with nasogastric and rectal tube placement alone is insufficient.

B) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is an option for decompression of the colon in patients with acute megacolon without concomitant peritonitis. Because this patient presents with signs of peritonitis, he needs a more aggressive approach to prevent bowel necrosis, sepsis, and death.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous neostigmine therapy is an effective pharmacologic treatment for acute megacolon in patients who do not respond to nonpharmacologic treatment after 24–48 hours and/or those with cecal dilation > 12 cm. However, this patient with signs of peritonitis requires a more aggressive approach to prevent bowel necrosis, sepsis, and death.

D) CORRECT:

Surgical decompression for acute megacolon is indicated for patients who do not respond to nonsurgical treatment, and for patients with bowel ischemia, peritonitis, and/or perforation of the colon. Because this patient presents with signs of bowel ischemia and peritonitis, he needs emergency surgical intervention to prevent further complications such as bowel necrosis, sepsis, shock. This patient will require a partial resection of the colon with primary anastomosis of the remaining ends of the colon or a (temporary) colostomy. Cecostomy tube placement would also be an option.

E) INCORRECT:

Although intravenous fluids are indicated in this patient, he is critically ill with signs of peritonitis and actual or impending bowel ischemia. Nonsurgical treatment with bowel rest is not sufficient.
questions.hint: Abdominal distention and marked dilation of the colon and cecum on imaging indicate acute megacolon. This condition typically occurs as a complication of an interventional procedure and/or a side effect of medications that are known to decrease intestinal motility (e.g., amlodipine, chlorpromazine). The combination of fever, tachycardia, abdominal rebound tenderness, and guarding suggests a case complicated by peritonitis and actual or impending bowel ischemia.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing abdominal pain and distention for 3 days. The pain is diffuse and colicky, and he describes it as 4 out of 10 in intensity. His last bowel movement was 5 days ago. He has not undergone any previous abdominal surgeries. He has hypertension, chronic lower back pain, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Prior to admission, his medications were enalapril, gabapentin, oxycodone, metoprolol, aspirin, and simvastatin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen; bowel sounds are reduced. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen with no guarding or rebound. Rectal examination shows an empty rectum. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Serum



 Na+

134 mEq/L


 K+

2.7 mEq/L


 Cl-

98 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
32 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1 mg/dL


An x-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated cecum and right colon and preservation of the haustrae. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast shows a cecal diameter of 11 cm. The patient is kept NPO and intravenous fluids with electrolytes are administered. A nasogastric tube and rectal tube are inserted. Thirty-six hours later, he still has abdominal pain. Examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen. Serum concentrations of electrolytes are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous cecostomy is performed with ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance and is an effective procedure for treating acute colonic pseudo-obstruction. However, because of the complications associated with this procedure (e.g., infection, hemorrhage), less invasive options are initially preferred in patients who do not require immediate decompression.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous neostigmine therapy is a highly effective treatment option for acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome) that is indicated if supportive therapy (i.e., bowel rest, intravenous fluids with correction of any electrolyte abnormalities, bowel decompression) does not relieve symptoms within 24–48 hours. As Ogilvie syndrome is thought to arise from an imbalance between adrenergic and cholinergic signaling, an increase in acetylcholine from neostigmine administration should stimulate bowel peristalsis and relieve symptoms in most patients.

In patients presenting with cecal dilatation > 12 cm, neostigmine therapy can also be used as initial therapy, if there are no signs of colonic ischemia, perforation, or peritonitis (e.g., fever, abdominal guarding or rebound) that necessitate surgery. Patients undergoing neostigmine therapy should be monitored for bradycardia, which is a common side effect.
Image Description:

Abdominal CT of a female patient (coronal view)

Intestinal loops are massively distended. Unlike in mechanical obstruction, there is no evidence of any anatomical structure or object blocking the intestinal passage. There is also no perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

Laparotomy is indicated in patients with acute colonic pseudo-obstruction that show signs and symptoms of acute abdomen indicating impending or current colonic ischemia and/or perforation, such as fever, rigid abdomen, guarding, or rebound tenderness. However, this patient is afebrile and his physical exam reveals a distended abdomen with only mild tenderness to palpation. A less aggressive treatment option is more appropriate in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is used to treat intestinal infections caused by Clostridioides difficile, which can lead to toxic megacolon. While toxic megacolon causes abdominal distention and colonic dilatation, it usually also manifests with features of intestinal infection, such as bloody diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and concomitant systemic symptoms, such as tachycardia or fever, none of which is seen here. Furthermore, toxic megacolon commonly leads to deformation or complete loss of colonic haustration on imaging, whereas this patient's x-ray shows preservation of the haustrae.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy with decompression of the bowel is a useful treatment option for patients with acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, with high rates of success. However, it is an invasive procedure that carries a ∼ 3% risk of perforation; therefore, other less invasive options should be attempted first.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of multiple medical conditions presents with abdominal distention and pain as well as radiographic evidence of colonic dilation with haustral preservation. In the absence of an obstructing lesion indicating mechanical bowel obstruction, these findings should raise concern for acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome), a condition characterized by impairment of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department for the evaluation of recurrent bloody diarrhea for 4 weeks. During this time, he has also had intermittent abdominal pain. His symptoms have worsened over the past 2 days and he has also had fever and several episodes of nonbloody vomiting. He was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis three years ago but has had difficulty adhering to his drug regimen. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 112/min and regular, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen with no guarding or rebound; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Hemoglobin concentration is 10.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 50 mm/h. Fluid resuscitation is initiated. In addition to complete bowel rest, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical sulfasalazine and oral prednisolone therapy
Intravenous metronidazole and rectal vancomycin therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indications for exploratory laparotomy for toxic megacolon include features of bowel perforation or ischemia (abdominal guarding, rebound tenderness, air under the diaphragm on radiography), massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and no improvement of symptoms after 24–72 hours of conservative therapy. This patient has no clinical signs of bowel ischemia or perforation and requires a confirmatory diagnostic test for toxic megacolon before initiating treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical sulfasalazine (suppositories) and oral prednisolone are the preferred treatment regimen in patients with severe ulcerative colitis, which is defined as ≥ 6 episodes of bloody diarrhea per day in combination with severe abdominal cramps, signs of systemic inflammation, and anemia. Although this patient fulfills most of the criteria for severe ulcerative colitis, the presence of abdominal distention on examination suggests toxic megacolon, which should first be confirmed before initiating treatment. After confirming the diagnosis of toxic megacolon, steroids should be administered intravenously rather than orally. Once this patient's toxic megacolon has resolved, treatment with topical sulfasalazine and oral prednisolone should follow.

C) CORRECT:

Plain abdominal x-ray and/or CT scan with contrast are used to diagnose toxic megacolon and should be ordered in patients who present with bloody diarrhea, abdominal distention, and signs of systemic inflammation. Radiographic evidence of colonic dilation (transverse colon > 6 cm in diameter) is needed to confirm the diagnosis. Multiple air-fluid levels and loss of colonic haustration further indicate colonic dilation and paralytic ileus. Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases such as ulcerative colitis are at risk of developing toxic megacolon, especially early in the disease course.

Initial treatment is usually conservative and includes IV antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, complete bowel rest, nasogastric decompression, and IV steroids (for inflammatory bowel disease). If the patient does not improve within 24–72 hours, surgery may be required.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a patient with ulcerative colitis

The transverse and the descending colon (green outline) are featureless, with a loss of haustral markings (cf. illustration). The transverse colon is dilated to a diameter > 6 cm and some pseudopolyps (examples indicated by red overlay) are visible.

The radiographic findings are characteristic of toxic megacolon.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is a confirmatory test used to diagnose acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI), which can manifest with an acute onset of bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and distention, and hypoactive bowel sounds. In patients with bowel necrosis, AMI can also manifest with signs of systemic inflammation and shock. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years of age with risk factors such as atrial fibrillation or valvular heart disease.

E) INCORRECT:

IV metronidazole and rectal vancomycin is the preferred treatment in patients with toxic megacolon due to Clostridioides difficile infection. As this patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, is not adherent to his treatment regimen, and has no history of recent antibiotic use, which is an important risk factor for C. difficile infection, he is more likely to have toxic megacolon due to an acute flare-up of ulcerative colitis. In either case, a clinical diagnosis of toxic megacolon should be confirmed before initiating treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Double-contrast barium enema is an imaging modality used in the investigation of undiagnosed ulcerative colitis because it can identify fine mucosal changes (e.g., microulcerations, pseudopolyps) that may be missed on other imaging modalities. However, the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis has already been established in this patient. More importantly, barium enema is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon because it would further increase colonic distension and thus risk causing colonic perforation.

G) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is used to diagnose inflammatory bowel diseases such as ulcerative colitis. This patient has signs consistent with toxic megacolon, which results in a grossly dilated colon that is friable due to transmural inflammation and bowel wall ischemia. Colonoscopy is therefore contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon because of the risk of colonic perforation.
questions.hint: Bloody diarrhea, severe abdominal distention and pain, and signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hypotension) in a patient with a history of ulcerative colitis and medication nonadherence should raise concern for toxic megacolon.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 5-week history of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea that has worsened in the past 24 hours. She was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 1 year ago but has had difficulty adhering to her drug regimen. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 92/56 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended, rigid abdomen and hypoactive bowel sounds. Fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Double-contrast barium enema is an imaging modality, which can be used in the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis because it can identify fine mucosal changes (e.g., microulcerations, pseudopolyps) that may be missed on other imaging modalities. However, the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis has already been established in this patient. More importantly, barium enema is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon because it would further increase colonic distension and thus risk colonic perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

A contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) has a limited role in the diagnosis of toxic megacolon. CT scan can be considered if the first-line diagnostic modality is inconclusive, or to better identify possible complications of toxic megacolon, such as perforation and bowel ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is a confirmatory test used to diagnose acute mesenteric ischemia, which can manifest with an acute onset of bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and distention, hypoactive bowel sounds, and, in case of bowel necrosis, signs of sepsis. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years with cardiovascular risk factors. This 32-year-old patient presents with a 5-week history of bloody diarrhea and she lacks risk factors for the development of AMI, such as atrial fibrillation, valvular heart disease, or a recent history of critical illness.

D) CORRECT:

Abdominal x-ray is the preferred diagnostic modality for toxic megacolon and should be ordered in all patients who present with bloody diarrhea, abdominal distention, and signs of sepsis. Dilation of the transverse colon > 6 cm on plain abdominal x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Loss of colonic haustration and multiple air-fluid levels indicate colonic dilation and paralytic ileus. Patients with inflammatory bowel disease, such as this patient, are at risk of developing toxic megacolon, especially early in the course of disease (∼ 5% lifetime risk).
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a patient with ulcerative colitis

The transverse and the descending colon (green outline) are featureless, with a loss of haustral markings (cf. illustration). The transverse colon is dilated to a diameter > 6 cm and some pseudopolyps (examples indicated by red overlay) are visible.

The radiographic findings are characteristic of toxic megacolon.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is useful for the diagnosis of inflammatory bowel diseases such as ulcerative colitis. However, patients with toxic megacolon have a grossly dilated colon that is often friable due to the transmural inflammation and bowel wall ischemia. This increases the risk of colonic perforation during colonoscopy, making it contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon.

Patients with ulcerative colitis are at increased risk of developing colorectal cancer. Screening colonoscopies with biopsies every 1–2 years are recommended 8–10 years after the initial diagnosis. Although colon cancer can also present with abdominal pain and distention, the features of sepsis in this 32-year-old patient are more consistent with toxic megacolon.
questions.hint: Toxic megacolon should be suspected in a patient with a history of ulcerative colitis and medication nonadherence who presents with bloody diarrhea, severe abdominal pain and distention, and signs of sepsis (fever, tachycardia, hypotension).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history of worsening abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and repeated vomiting. He has had intermittent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past several months, but the symptoms were never as severe as now. Over-the-counter acetaminophen did not relieve his symptoms. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 121/min, and blood pressure is 95/64 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a distended abdomen. On palpation of the abdomen, the patient groans in pain; bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
17,000/mm3


Platelet count
220,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

135 mEq/L


 K+

3.1 mEq/L


 Cl-

99 mEq/L


 Glucose
98 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

GI tract perforation manifests with signs of peritonitis, such as severe abdominal pain, vomiting, fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis. However, an x-ray of the abdomen would show air under the diaphragm and/or air delineating the bowel wall (i.e., signs of pneumoperitoneum) rather than the extensive colonic dilation seen here.
Image Description:

Posteroanterior chest x-ray showing a large amount of intraabdominal free gas (green area) that contours the diaphragm (white dashed line). Free gas in the peritoneal cavity indicates pneumoperitoneum, which is often a sign of critical illness.

B) INCORRECT:

Sigmoid volvulus can manifest with abdominal pain and vomiting. However, this condition typically affects elderly adults (mean age of 70 years) and manifests with constipation rather than bloody diarrhea. Moreover, an abdominal x-ray would show a dilated sigmoid colon resembling a coffee bean rather than the extensive colonic dilation seen in this patient.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (left lateral decubitus view)

Gaseous distention of a closed loop of sigmoid colon (red overlay) has caused apposition of the medial walls (green lines). The resultant cleft-like configuration, in conjunction with the lateral walls of the loop, produces an appearance reminiscent of a coffee bean (illustration).

The coffee bean sign (also called “kidney-bean sign” or “bent-inner-tube sign”) is a classic conventional radiographic finding of sigmoid volvulus.

Dashed line: air-fluid level

C) INCORRECT:

Ogilvie syndrome (acute colonic pseudo-obstruction) can manifest with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and, in cases of colonic ischemia or impending perforation, fever and tachycardia. Moreover, an x-ray of the abdomen would show extensive colonic distention, as seen here. However, Ogilvie syndrome does not typically cause bloody diarrhea and characteristically occurs in seriously ill or postoperative patients.

D) INCORRECT:

C. difficile colitis can manifest with abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, leukocytosis, and hypokalemia due to diarrhea. Moreover, C. difficile colitis may in some cases lead to dilation of the colon and loss of haustration on abdominal x-ray. However, diarrhea is typically watery and C. difficile infection usually develops following recent antibiotic treatment, making this diagnosis less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI) can manifest with bloody diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain and distention, absent bowel sounds, and, in cases of bowel necrosis, signs of sepsis. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years of age with cardiovascular risk factors, which this 45-year-old patient lacks. Moreover, an x-ray of the abdomen would be more likely to show pneumatosis intestinalis or indentations in the bowel wall caused by haustral edema (i.e., thumb sign) than the extensive colonic dilation seen here.

F) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory conditions affecting the intestines like ulcerative colitis, which this patient, with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, most likely has. To diagnose toxic megacolon, there must be radiographic evidence of colonic dilation (transverse colon diameter > 6 cm) and three of the following features must be present: fever, tachycardia (> 120/min), leukocytosis (> 10,500/mm3), and anemia. Furthermore, one of the following must be present: dehydration, hypotension, altered mental status, or electrolyte disturbance (e.g., hypokalemia, as seen here). The initial treatment is conservative (including IV antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, complete bowel rest, nasogastric decompression, and IV steroids for inflammatory bowel disease), but surgery may be required if there is no response to medical management within 24–72 hours.

Toxic megacolon is also a potential complication of infectious colitis due to bacteria (e.g., C. difficile, Salmonella) or parasites (e.g., E. histolytica).
questions.hint: This patient's abdominal x-ray shows severe colonic dilation and loss of haustration. Colonoscopy should be avoided in this condition.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with pan-ulcerative colitis (UC) who was previously maintained in remission on oral and rectal mesalamine is hospitalized for a severe UC flare.
After 3 days of treatment with intravenous hydration, intravenous methylprednisolone 60 mg daily, and supportive blood transfusions, his symptoms have not improved. Flexible sigmoidoscopy shows severe UC without cytomegalovirus infection.
On day 4 of the hospitalization, the patient’s abdominal pain becomes worse. His temperature is 39.0°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 98/63 mm Hg. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended and diffusely tender to palpation but without guarding.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
10.0
13.5–17.5



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
14,200
4500–11,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.8–1.3


Albumin (g/dL)
3.2
3.5–5.5


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
120
125–200


An abdominal radiograph reveals a dilated transverse colon to 8 cm but no free air.
In addition to starting broad-spectrum antibiotics, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient at this point?

choices.text: Perform urgent colectomy with end ileostomy
Monitor closely and consider surgery if further colonic dilatation occurs

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the setting of toxic megacolon, increasing the methylprednisolone dose or adding infliximab or sulfasalazine has no advantage, and further delay in surgical therapy may result in increased risk for morbidity and mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

In the setting of toxic megacolon, increasing the methylprednisolone dose or adding infliximab or sulfasalazine has no advantage, and further delay in surgical therapy may result in increased risk for morbidity and mortality.

C) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis is defined as nonobstructive total or segmental colonic dilatation (>5.5 cm) associated with systemic toxicity. Appropriate management includes urgent surgical consultation, with urgent subtotal or total colectomy and end ileostomy typically being the procedure of choice.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management of toxic megacolon complicating refractory ulcerative colitis is subtotal or total colectomy and end ileostomy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although adding antibiotics is appropriate, it would not be sufficient alone to prevent morbidity and mortality from toxic megacolon. Other indications for operative intervention in severe ulcerative colitis include severe hemorrhage, perforation, peritonitis, and failure of rescue therapy with infliximab or cyclosporine.

E) INCORRECT:

In the setting of toxic megacolon, increasing the methylprednisolone dose or adding infliximab or sulfasalazine has no advantage, and further delay in surgical therapy may result in increased risk for morbidity and mortality.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man reports abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting with any oral intake 3 days after an L4-5 laminectomy, synovial cyst resection, and L4-5 pedicle-screw fixation. Since the surgery, he has passed only a small amount of watery stool.
He has no history of constipation and had a normal screening colonoscopy 6 months ago. His medical history is remarkable only for hypertension controlled on lisinopril and a total left hip replacement 3 years ago for osteoarthritis.
On examination, he is afebrile with a blood pressure of 122/80 mm Hg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. His abdomen is distended and tympanitic, with no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are present.
An electrocardiogram is unremarkable.
Laboratory testing reveals a normal leukocyte count and a potassium level of 3.4 mEq/liter (reference range, 3.5 - 5.0). An abdominal radiograph is obtained (figure).
Despite the insertion of nasogastric and rectal tubes, and administration of intravenous fluids with potassium, his abdominal distention persists.
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Placement of a percutaneous cecostomy tube

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous cecostomy tube placement is reserved for patients who fail endoscopic decompression.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactulose can increase gas production and should be avoided.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopic decompression is typically reserved for patients who have failed conservative management and have contraindications to neostigmine.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgery is rarely necessary and is performed only in patients who fail medical and endoscopic therapy or who have signs of perforation.

E) CORRECT:

Ogilvie syndrome, or acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, is large-bowel dilation without evidence of mechanical obstruction. It is thought to result from alterations in the autonomic regulation of colonic motor function. Predisposing conditions include trauma, orthopedic surgery (as in this case), abdominal/pelvic surgery, caesarian section, infections, cardiac conditions such as myocardial infarction and heart failure, underlying neurologic conditions such as Parkinson disease and Alzheimer disease, metabolic disturbances such as hypokalemia, and medications including opioids.

The abdominal radiograph shows diffuse colonic dilation with air extending all the way to the rectum. First-line therapy for acute colonic pseudo-obstruction is conservative management. If conservative measures fail, neostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that stimulates colonic motility, can be administered. In a randomized, placebo-controlled trial, neostigmine was shown to be an effective treatment in patients with a cecal diameter of > 10 cm who had failed 24 hours of conservative management. Patients should be monitored closely during the administration of neostigmine because bradycardia can occur.

Key learning point: A patient with acute colonic pseudo-obstruction who has not responded to placement of nasogastric and rectal tubes should be treated with intravenous neostigmine, as long as the patient has no contraindications (e.g., severe bronchospasm, recent myocardial infarction, or known bradyarrhythmias).

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman who was admitted to the intensive care unit 5 days ago with respiratory failure in the setting of bacterial pneumonia is found to have a distended abdomen. She is currently intubated and sedated. She has not had a bowel movement for the past 5 days. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stage 3 chronic kidney disease.
On examination, she has a temperature of 37.1°C, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 124/82 mm Hg. Her abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds, and percussion of the abdomen reveals tympany.
An abdominal radiograph shows an air-filled colon, with significant dilation of the cecum and transverse colon, measuring approximately 12 cm (figure). CT of the patient’s abdomen reveals significant dilation of the cecum and transverse colon, with decompressed descending colon and no obstructing lesions.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small-bowel obstructions often manifest with nausea, vomiting, and lack of bowel movements. Abdominal radiography and CT would show dilated loops of small bowel rather than a dilated colon.

B) INCORRECT:

Colon cancer can manifest with a large-bowel obstruction and lack of stool production. However, an obstructing lesion would be seen on CT, and an acute presentation in the setting of severe illness would be rare.

C) INCORRECT:

Colonic perforation can occur secondary to a variety of causes, including acute colonic pseudo-obstruction, diverticulitis, severe colitis, colon cancer, and colonoscopy. In general, an upright abdominal radiograph would show free air below the diaphragm, and CT would show evidence of a perforation.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has acute dilation of her colon with an air-filled cecum and transverse colon but no evidence of an obstructing lesion. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome). This condition can occur in the setting of a variety of medical and surgical illnesses and is more common with severe illness. Treatment can include intravenous fluids, electrolyte repletion, a rectal tube for decompression, neostigmine, and colonoscopic decompression.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of acute dilation of the colon with air in the setting of severe illness, but in the absence of an obstructing lesion, is acute colonic pseudo-obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a complication of severe colitis (often secondary to ulcerative colitis or Clostridioides difficile infection), which manifests with systemic symptoms including fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status. This patient has normal vital signs and no history of colitis, making toxic megacolon unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI) can manifest with bloody diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain and distention, absent bowel sounds, and, in cases of bowel necrosis, signs of sepsis. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years of age with cardiovascular risk factors, which this 45-year-old patient lacks. Moreover, an x-ray of the abdomen would be more likely to show pneumatosis intestinalis or indentations in the bowel wall caused by haustral edema (i.e., thumb sign) than the extensive colonic dilation seen here.

E) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory conditions affecting the intestines like ulcerative colitis, which this patient, with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, most likely has. To diagnose toxic megacolon, there must be radiographic evidence of colonic dilation (transverse colon diameter > 6 cm) and three of the following features must be present: fever, tachycardia (> 120/min), leukocytosis (> 10,500/mm3), and anemia. Furthermore, one of the following must be present: dehydration, hypotension, altered mental status, or electrolyte disturbance (e.g., hypokalemia, as seen here). The initial treatment is conservative (including IV antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, complete bowel rest, nasogastric decompression, and IV steroids for inflammatory bowel disease), but surgery may be required if there is no response to medical management within 24–72 hours.

Toxic megacolon is also a potential complication of infectious colitis due to bacteria (e.g., C. difficile, Salmonella) or parasites (e.g., E. histolytica).
questions.hint: This patient's abdominal x-ray shows severe colonic dilation and loss of haustration. Colonoscopy should be avoided in this condition.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and increasing distension over the past 48 hours to the hospital. He has a 4-year history of ulcerative colitis and reports 10–12 bloody, watery bowel movements per day. Physical examination reveals a markedly distended, tender abdomen with decreased bowel sounds. Despite 72 hours of intravenous corticosteroids, he remains febrile and his abdomen becomes exquisitely tender (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
118/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Temperature
39.0°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
19 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Abdominal radiograph: Colonic dilation of 9 cm in the transverse colon
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopic decompression is used in conditions like sigmoid volvulus, but in toxic megacolon, the inflamed and edematous colonic wall increases the risk of perforation. The 9 cm dilation indicates a vulnerable colon, making decompression risky and inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing corticosteroids may seem reasonable for a severe ulcerative colitis flare, but this patient has progressed to toxic megacolon, evidenced by systemic toxicity and colonic dilation. The inflammatory process is unresponsive to further medical therapy, and increasing corticosteroids will not reverse colonic dilation or systemic toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Infliximab is used for severe ulcerative colitis unresponsive to corticosteroids, but not in toxic megacolon. The patient's colonic dilation and systemic toxicity indicate a high risk of perforation, and further immunosuppression could delay necessary surgical intervention.

D) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a severe complication of ulcerative colitis characterized by colonic dilation (≥6 cm) and systemic toxicity. This patient exhibits systemic signs such as fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and leukocytosis, along with colonic dilation on imaging, despite 72 hours of intravenous corticosteroids. These findings indicate failure of medical management and an increased risk of perforation and sepsis. Total colectomy with end ileostomy is the definitive treatment, removing the diseased colon and preventing life-threatening complications.

Key learning point: In cases of toxic megacolon due to ulcerative colitis, if medical management fails or if there are signs of perforation, a total colectomy with end ileostomy is the appropriate surgical intervention.

You are caring for a 45-year-old man who is admitted to hospital with a 1-week history of worsening abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and repeated vomiting. He reports having intermittent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain over the past several months, but his current symptoms are more severe. His temperature is 38.8°C, pulse is 121/min, and blood pressure is 95/64 mm Hg. On abdominal examination, his abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory studies show:

An abdominal x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) INCORRECT:

Acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI) can manifest with bloody diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain and distention, absent bowel sounds, and, in cases of bowel necrosis, signs of sepsis. However, AMI usually occurs in patients > 60 years of age with cardiovascular risk factors, which this 45-year-old patient lacks. Moreover, an x-ray of the abdomen would be more likely to show pneumatosis intestinalis or indentations in the bowel wall caused by haustral edema (i.e., thumb sign) than the extensive colonic dilation seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory conditions affecting the intestines like ulcerative colitis, which this patient, with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, most likely has. To diagnose toxic megacolon, there must be radiographic evidence of colonic dilation (transverse colon diameter > 6 cm) and three of the following features must be present: fever, tachycardia (> 120/min), leukocytosis (> 10,5 × 109/L), and anemia. Furthermore, one of the following must be present: dehydration, hypotension, altered mental status, or electrolyte disturbance (e.g., hypokalemia, as seen here). The initial treatment is conservative (including IV antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, complete bowel rest, nasogastric decompression, and IV steroids for inflammatory bowel disease), but surgery may be required if there is no response to medical management within 24–72 hours.

Toxic megacolon is also a potential complication of infectious colitis due to bacteria (e.g., C. difficile, Salmonella) or parasites (e.g., E. histolytica).

Key learning point: Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of colitis characterized by severe systemic toxicity and radiographic evidence of colonic dilation.

C) INCORRECT:

C. difficile colitis can manifest with abdominal pain, diarrhea, fever, leukocytosis, and hypokalemia due to diarrhea. Moreover, C. difficile colitis may in some cases lead to dilation of the colon and loss of haustration on abdominal x-ray. However, diarrhea is typically watery and C. difficile infection usually develops following recent antibiotic treatment, making this diagnosis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Sigmoid volvulus can manifest with abdominal pain and vomiting. However, this condition typically affects elderly adults (mean age of 70 years) and manifests with constipation rather than bloody diarrhea. Moreover, an abdominal x-ray would show a dilated sigmoid colon resembling a coffee bean rather than the extensive colonic dilation seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

GI tract perforation manifests with signs of peritonitis, such as severe abdominal pain, vomiting, fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis. However, an x-ray of the abdomen would show air under the diaphragm and/or air delineating the bowel wall (i.e., signs of pneumoperitoneum) rather than the extensive colonic dilation seen here.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with 3 days of worsening abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. He appears ill. Vital signs: T 39.2 °C (102.6 °F), P, 128; BP 86/54. Physical examination shows marked abdominal distention, diffuse tenderness, and hypoactive bowel sounds. Labs: WBC 13,200/μL, hemoglobin 8.0 g/dL, potassium 2.9 mEq/L. Abdominal x-ray is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT enterography to evaluate small bowel involvement
Surgical consultation for subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in toxic megacolon because the friable, dilated colon wall is at high risk for perforation with instrumentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Supportive measures such as bowel rest are part of stabilization, but are not sufficient alone in toxic megacolon.

C) INCORRECT:

CT enterography is not indicated in this acute setting. The patient requires immediate surgical intervention given the unsuccessful conservative management and risk of colonic perforation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets diagnostic criteria for toxic megacolon: colonic dilation plus systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis, hypotension). The priority is immediate surgical consultation. Medical stablization can be started concurrently.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy is contraindicated in toxic megacolon due to the high risk of colonic perforation. The inflamed and dilated colon is fragile, and endoscopic manipulation can cause rupture.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening diffuse abdominal pain and profuse bloody diarrhea. He also reports a feeling of incomplete evacuation after passing a stool. He has a history of ulcerative colitis. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 128/min, blood pressure is 94/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 26/min. He appears lethargic and confused. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanitic abdomen with diminished bowel sounds and diffuse tenderness without rebound. An upright abdominal radiograph demonstrates a transverse colon diameter of 9 cm with a loss of haustral markings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Colonic perforation is a major concern in this patient and can manifest with abdominal pain and signs of sepsis. However, the hallmark radiographic finding of perforation and pneumoperitoneum (free air under the diaphragm) is not described. The primary diagnosis is supported by the radiographic finding of a 9 cm dilated colon and is a major risk factor for subsequent perforation.

B) INCORRECT:

While this patient is experiencing a severe ulcerative colitis flare, this diagnosis is incomplete. The presence of systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, hypotension, confusion) and significant colonic dilation (9 cm) on imaging indicates a progression to the specific, life-threatening complication, which requires a distinct and more aggressive management approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Ischemic colitis can present with acute abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea, and this patient's hypotension is a risk factor. However, the known history of ulcerative colitis and the extreme degree of colonic dilation (9 cm) are much more characteristic of another complication. Ischemic colitis typically does not cause such massive, non-obstructive colonic distension.

D) INCORRECT:

A small bowel obstruction could cause abdominal distension and diminished bowel sounds. However, the patient reports profuse diarrhea, whereas obstipation is more typical for a complete obstruction. Furthermore, the radiograph specifically identifies dilation of the transverse colon, not the small bowel, which would be the primary finding in a small bowel obstruction.

E) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory bowel disease, particularly ulcerative colitis. The diagnosis is made based on radiographic evidence of colonic dilation (typically transverse colon >6 cm) plus signs of systemic toxicity. This patient demonstrates profound toxicity with high fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status. The abdominal radiograph confirms colonic dilation of 9 cm with loss of haustra. Pathophysiologically, severe inflammation extends into the muscularis propria, leading to paralysis, impaired motility, and subsequent dilation. Management involves aggressive fluid resuscitation, broad-spectrum antibiotics, corticosteroids, and urgent surgical consultation, as perforation is a significant risk.
questions.hint: The radiographic findings of a dilated colon and loss of haustral markings are characteristic features of this syndrome.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis is brought to the emergency department for a 3-day history of worsening abdominal pain, high fever, and bloody diarrhea. She reports over 15 bowel movements per day. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. On examination, she appears lethargic and distressed. Her abdomen is markedly distended, tympanitic, and diffusely tender to light palpation. Bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 22,000/mm³. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory bowel disease, particularly ulcerative colitis. It is characterized by non-obstructive colonic dilation accompanied by systemic toxicity. This patient's marked abdominal distention, tympany, and absent bowel sounds suggest colonic dilation and ileus. The diagnosis is further supported by clear signs of systemic toxicity, including high fever, tachycardia, hypotension, lethargy, and significant leukocytosis. The underlying pathophysiology involves severe inflammation extending into the muscularis propria, leading to paralysis of the colonic smooth muscle and subsequent dilation. An abdominal x-ray showing a colonic diameter greater than 6 cm would confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bowel perforation is a potential complication of severe colitis and may manifest with diffuse abdominal tenderness and signs of systemic toxicity. However, this patient's clinical presentation, especially the marked abdominal distention and tympany, is most characteristic of the underlying process that leads to perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

Small bowel obstruction can cause abdominal distention, pain, and absent bowel sounds. However, it is typically associated with nausea, vomiting, and obstipation (inability to pass stool or flatus). This patient's presentation with over 15 bloody bowel movements per day is inconsistent with a mechanical obstruction and suggests a severe inflammatory colonic process.

D) INCORRECT:

A severe flare is defined by criteria such as high stool frequency, fever, and tachycardia. However, the presence of marked abdominal distention, absent bowel sounds, and profound systemic toxicity (hypotension, lethargy) suggests a specific, life-threatening complication rather than just a severe flare.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a 10-year history of ulcerative colitis is brought to the emergency department due to worsening abdominal pain, fever, and bloody diarrhea over the past 24 hours. She appears unwell and lethargic. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows significant distention and diffuse tenderness. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on examination?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of toxic megacolon, a life-threatening complication of ulcerative colitis. The pathophysiology involves severe inflammation extending through the colonic wall to the muscularis propria, leading to smooth muscle paralysis and subsequent colonic dilation. This paralysis results in an adynamic ileus, which manifests clinically as diminished or absent bowel sounds on auscultation. The diagnosis is confirmed with an abdominal x-ray showing colonic dilation, typically > 6 cm in the transverse colon, loss of haustration, and multiple air-fluid levels. Management is focused on bowel rest, IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and corticosteroids, with surgical consultation for a potential colectomy if the patient's condition does not improve or worsens.

B) INCORRECT:

A positive Murphy sign, which is characterized by inspiratory arrest during deep palpation of the right upper quadrant, is a specific finding for acute cholecystitis. This patient's symptoms of bloody diarrhea and diffuse abdominal tenderness, along with a history of ulcerative colitis, are inconsistent with a primary gallbladder pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperactive bowel sounds, or borborygmi, are associated with increased peristalsis. This can be seen in conditions such as gastroenteritis or early mechanical small bowel obstruction. Although this patient has diarrhea, this patient's signs of systemic toxicity and significant abdominal distention suggest colonic paralysis from severe inflammation, not hyperperistalsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Shifting dullness is a physical examination finding that indicates the presence of significant ascites (free fluid in the peritoneal cavity). Although severe inflammation can cause a small amount of reactive fluid, ascites is not a characteristic feature of toxic megacolon. This patient's abdominal distention is caused by massive dilation of the gas-filled colon, not fluid accumulation.

E) INCORRECT:

A palpable inflammatory mass (phlegmon) or abscess in the right lower quadrant is a potential complication of inflammatory bowel disease. However, this finding is much more characteristic of Crohn disease, which commonly affects the terminal ileum. This patient's history of ulcerative colitis and diffuse abdominal findings make a localized mass less likely.
questions.hint: This patient's history of ulcerative colitis combined with signs of systemic toxicity (fever, tachycardia, and hypotension) and significant abdominal distention suggests a life-threatening complication of inflammatory bowel disease.
